Opposes Oath
We are maintaining our organized
opposition to a Maryland teachers'
oath bill. We led the protest of our
student body against an expressed attack upon our freedom of speech. We
secured the invaluable cooperation of
a dozen other campus organizations
in sponsoring our strike against war

which drew half our undergraduates
from their classes last April 22.
This year, the program of the Hopkins chapter of the American Student Union revolves around preparations for the strike against war next
April. It calls also for a series of
educational talks, for discussion and
activity on the N.Y.A., and for continued resistance to gag legislation.

Twenty-Three
Men Take Part
In Pi Lam Win
Entire Fraternity Participates
As Last Year's Champions
Conquer TAO
Still displaying the form that carried them to the inter-fraternity football championship last year,a powerful Pi Lam team defeated an unorganized TAO seven, Wednesday, to the
tune of 44-0.
Captain Margolis and M. Breslaw
led the touchdown parade followed by
W. Baratz and B. Wall who each contributed one. Pi Lam had a twentythree man team on the field which
constituted the entire fraternity.
S. P. E. Downs Psi
Climaxing the second year of intense rivalry, S.P.E. finally decisively defeated Phi Psi by a score of 14-0.
Unlike last year when four games had
to be played to decide the better team,
S.P.E. made short work of what would
have ended as another marathon. D.
Erck and R. Watkins crossed the goal
line for a touchdown apiece, while
M. Dietz was responsible for the remaining two points by scoring a safety. Leading the futile Phi Psi attack
and starring on the defense was J.
Himes.
In other encounters Delta Upsilon
topped Alpha Delta Phi 18-0 and Pi
Lambda Phi conquered Alpha Epsilon
Pi by the same score. MacShane and H.
Beeler crossed the chalk lines for
Delta Upsilon. Steven's playing and
the work of Canning on the line were
features of the game. Yearley performed well for the losers, and if
the A.D.'s had more practice the result

Opposes Oath
We are maintaining our organized
opposition to a Maryland teachers'
oath bill. We led the protest of our
student body against an expressed attack upon our freedom of speech. We
secured the invaluable cooperation of
a dozen other campus organizations
in sponsoring our strike against war

which drew half our undergraduates
from their classes last April 22.
This year, the program of the Hopkins chapter of the American Student Union revolves around preparations for the strike against war next
April. It calls also for a series of
educational talks, for discussion and
activity on the N.Y.A., and for continued resistance to gag legislation.
Here, in this time of a world marching to war and of nations facing fascist oppression, is a program for the
American student.

Twenty-Three
Men Take Part
In Pi Lam Win
Entire Fraternity Participates
As Last Year's Champions
Conquer TAO
Still displaying the form that carried them to the inter-fraternity football championship last year,a powerful Pi Lam team defeated an unorganized TAO seven, Wednesday, to the
tune of 44-0.
Captain Margolis and M. Breslaw
led the touchdown parade followed by
W. Baratz and B. Wall who each contributed one. Pi Lam had a twentythree man team on the field which
constituted the entire fraternity.
S. P. E. Downs Psi
Climaxing the second year of intense rivalry, S.P.E. finally decisively defeated Phi Psi by a score of 14-0.
Unlike last year when four games had
to be played to decide the better team,
S.P.E. made short work of what would
have ended as another marathon. D.
Erck and R. Watkins crossed the goal
line for a touchdown apiece, while
M. Dietz was responsible for the remaining two points by scoring a safety. Leading the futile Phi Psi attack
and starring on the defense was J.
Himes.
In other encounters Delta Upsilon
topped Alpha Delta Phi 18-0 and Pi
Lambda Phi conquered Alpha Epsilon
Pi by the same score. MacShane and H.
Beeler crossed the chalk lines for
Delta Upsilon. Steven's playing and
the work of Canning on the line were
features of the game. Yearley performed well for the losers, and if
the A.D.'s had more practice the result
